Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
My neighborhood in this big city is a real mix of everything! Houses and stores are scattered around, like someone just threw them down randomly. You've got your usual shops and restaurants, but there are always new places popping up. Some are big chains, but I see more and more little, independent stores opening up too. They're everywhere, even on quiet streets, which makes it fun to explore. There are a couple of parks nearby, and it's adorable to see families with little kids playing there.

Now, the people here are just as diverse as the places. There's a whole LGBTQ+ community, a group of Orthodox Jews, and even a bunch of people who came here from the former Soviet Union, all in one little area. 

If you go a bit further out, you'll find even more different cultures. There's Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and tons more, all within a short drive...though,  "short" can be a bit relative in this city! Traffic can be brutal, especially during rush hour, so a 10-mile drive can take forever. 

It's funny, because everyone drives everywhere, but nobody walks. There are things to see and do nearby, but this city is huge! People just don't want to walk that far.  So, we've got some of the worst traffic in the world and parking is a nightmare.  

And get this: even with all the traffic and parking problems, they keep building more apartments! It seems like everyone wants to live here, but some people are worried about even more people and cars crowding the streets.

But hey, not everyone wants to live in a giant apartment building.  There are tons of houses of all sizes,  duplexes, and smaller apartment complexes.  It's a mix of everything, just like the people!

There are all ages here too, and to be honest, I don't really know most of my neighbors. It's not like the tight-knit neighborhood I grew up in, where I spent all my time playing outside with my friends. Back then, we were practically inseparable.

My neighbourhood, its a real character, ya know? Most of the houses are those big ol' single family ones, but some folks have split theirs up, like joining two houses together, but still keeping them separate. My place has a little patch of grass out front and a tiny driveway to the side. It's like a snapshot from a time when living in the suburbs was the big dream, the American dream, you understand? It felt like everyone was chasing it back then, but now, it's like the dream's kinda slipping away. 

But my neighbourhood, and a whole bunch of others like it, they're still holding on. They're shoutin' out, "Hey, the dream's still alive!" We're clingin' to it with all we got. Folks ain't as bright-eyed and bushy-tailed as they used to be, the lawns ain't quite as perfect, but there's still cars parkin' in every driveway, and kids playin' like the world's their own playground.  

That old school, been standin' for almost 90 years, it's still there, makin' dreams for the young'uns and bringin' back memories for the old-timers.  Churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are always buzzin'. Each house looks different, but they all kinda feel the same, like they got that same old soul.

We got this big supermarket, "Super A," owned by this big Yemeni family, they might be the only ones from around there in the whole neighbourhood. Mostly everyone else is African American. Streets are wide, kids playin' football like it's the only thing that matters, only stop when the cars come by. Most folks here have been here forever, got stories about the good ol' days when everyone knew everyone.

Used to be a karate school, but Hollywood stopped makin' those "Karate Kid" movies, so the kids lost interest. Now it's a pharmacy, guess drugs are the new craze. There's also this tiny movie theatre, shows old flicks for cheap. The young folks mock it, but the older folks love it, a night out without the kids, for a steal.

We got this one big highway runnin' through town, but the on-ramp and off-ramp are in the next town over. Back in the day, folks tried to get an exit here, but the young'uns wanted it, the old folks said it'd ruin the town, and well, they got their way. 

Now they're building a new high school, and we're tryin' to pick a mascot. I reckon a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the perfect fit for this place.

Okay, so you might just breeze past this place, thinking it's nothin' special. It's tucked away behind some shops, not exactly the kind of spot you'd expect to find a whole community, ya know? But hang on, because if you sneak past the old, forgotten Whole Foods and wander behind those hotels that only get filled up once a year, maybe for family get-togethers, you'll stumble onto a whole world you never knew existed.  

There are these apartment buildings lined up like a bunch of Russian nesting dolls, all carefully taken apart and put back together in a row. Now, the first ones you see, they've been on the news for some shady stuff, so let's not dwell on those too much. But the ones next to them, and the ones after those, those are a whole different story. Almost nobody around here even knows they're there.  

Across from those apartments, you'll find a little community college branch - a quiet place with sleepy buildings, where students amble in with their coffee cups, yawning their way into the 7 AM morning. The iron gates creak open, letting them in one by one, while the commuters in their cars shake their fists and grumble about them holding up traffic on busy days. The road bumps into another residential street, with a park on one side and a place where people go to heal up after getting hurt. They call it a rehabilitation center, and it's got these cheerful porch chairs and a lazy ceiling fan that keeps the warm summer air moving. 

Kids are running around in the park across the street, cartwheeling and spinning like crazy, while bees buzz around the flower patches by the road. Old folks walk their dogs, grumbling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding politely at the teenage girls hanging out by the swings, chatting about boys and the latest TikTok trends.  There's a sushi place in a strip mall next to the park, with cheap eats but never too crowded. Right beside it is a swimming supply store, and stuck in between is a nail salon. You could fill your pool, get your nails done, and grab some hibachi chicken, all in one go – that's the beauty of a strip mall. There's even a frozen yogurt place there, the kind where you build your own sundae, and you see the teens from the park all the time, holding their cold, drippy cups of frozen yogurt while they try out tricks on their skateboards and puff away on their vapes, thinking they look super cool.  

This whole neighborhood, it's like a snapshot of America, a little piece of history in the sleepy south where things just stay the same, even time seems to slow down.

"Where is everything?" she asked, her voice tinged with wonder as we drove past endless rows of cornfields.  I knew she wouldn't understand this vast expanse. She came from a town where the grocery store was a stone's throw away, where life was a constant buzz of activity.  I smiled, taking her hand. "This is it," I said, letting her feel the quiet hum of the countryside.

She gaped at the horizon, her eyes wide with a mixture of awe and disbelief. It was in these stretches of quiet, under the watchful gaze of the cornfields, that I truly felt at home. I told her stories of my childhood here in Ohio, of the summers filled with fireflies and the winters blanketed in snow. I painted pictures with my words, sharing the rhythm of life in a place where time seemed to move a little slower.

We passed a quarry, its water shimmering like a jewel in the sun. Just beyond it, nestled amongst the rolling hills, was my neighborhood. Brick and stucco homes, each with a sprawling yard, lined the roads.  People took pride in their gardens, bursting with color in the spring and autumn. Shiny Mercedes Benzes, gleaming after a good wash, lined the driveways, a testament to the success of those who called this place home.

A friendly face greeted us as we neared my house. My Korean neighbor, a retired doctor, was always out tending his lawn, humming a tune as his mower hummed. We all loved his quirky ways, his sunny disposition never faltering, even as time etched lines on his face.  He was a reminder that life, despite its challenges, could still be filled with simple joys.

My house stood at the end of a quiet lane, its grey stucco walls blending with the surrounding landscape. Geese honked in the side yard, chased playfully by our energetic terrier.  In the backyard, a small stream gurgled, its melody punctuated by the croaking of bullfrogs and the distant moo of cows.

A hand-built wooden bridge crossed the stream, leading to a secret oasis. A haven of trees, herbs, and wildflowers, it was here that I spent countless hours as a child. Building forts, chasing squirrels, exploring the woods - it was a world of endless possibilities.

Winter transformed the landscape into a stark, beautiful canvas. The vibrant greens faded, replaced by a tapestry of browns and grays. Snow blanketed the world, transforming the ordinary into something magical. My sister and I would build snow forts, armed with snowballs and laughter. We'd carve out igloos, our makeshift arsenals filled with branches, our imaginations running wild.

Those winters were tough, but they were also filled with a special kind of magic.  The snow brought a sense of wonder, a reminder that even in the coldest of times, there was beauty to be found.

We were just kids then, lost in our own little world. We didn't know anything about the world beyond the snow-covered fields and our backyard haven. We just knew that we had each other, and that was all that mattered.

Ah, Portland, Oregon... You gotta understand what "weird" truly means here. It's not just a quirky badge, it's woven into the very fabric of the city. This idea, you see, is immortalized on a building that somehow manages to be a pizza place, a bar, a music venue, a strip club, and probably a few other things that could land its owner in hot water.  It says, "Keep Portland Weird."  Some folks, they see it as a nostalgic shout-out to the Portland of the 90s and early 2000s, a time before it became a hot spot for Californians with deep pockets and a fondness for high-rise condos. They remember a Portland that was more hidden, more affordable, a breeding ground for unique and amazing subcultures. Others, well, they hear it as a siren song, a beckoning to a place where weird isn't just tolerated, it's celebrated.  

But let me tell you, even with all those fancy new condos popping up and the influx of folks from across the bridge, Portland still holds onto its weird.  

Now, weird doesn't mean everyone's always cool with everything. It doesn't mean we don't have our share of modern problems and modern conveniences, like everyone else. We buy our stuff from China, just like the rest of the country. There are a million ways to be weird, to be outside the norm, but Portland has plenty of "normal" too. We've got our yoga enthusiasts, our hipsters, our business folks, the whole shebang.  Maybe "weird" just means we take it all a little less seriously. 

Take my neighborhood, for example. It's like a kaleidoscope of color. Houses painted in every shade imaginable, gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the sidewalks. And in the summertime, there's this magical thing called "free boxes." They're filled with treasures,  clothes, books, you name it!  You never know what you'll find, but it's always a surprise.

That's the magic of walking through a neighborhood in Southeast Portland. It's about the unexpected, the embracing of the unusual. That's what Portland is all about to me, anyway.  But hey, I'm just one weird person among thousands. Some folks I know wouldn't dream of digging through a box on the sidewalk. They're off doing goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats!) or cheering on the Timbers (the city's soccer team). Portland is a melting pot of passions, dreams, and well, maybe a few too many beers at the bar.

Of course, we're not perfect. Like anywhere else, we have our problems. Drugs are a struggle, often rooted in deeper mental health issues. The constant rain and gray skies might not help matters. And then there's homelessness, a problem that seems to have no easy solutions. We have good social services, which attract people in need, but they're not enough.

The non-homeless folks, they wrestle with feelings of compassion and frustration. We're not so weird after all, in that way.

The mountains, they're always there. Up north, watching the sun rise and set every day.  Even when I'm caught up in work and life, forgetting about them, they're still there. Strong, steady, unbothered by all the craziness.  But on the days when I'm totally stressed out, when my heart is racing, those mountains call to me.  When I turn to them, they give me a sense of peace, a little strength to keep going.

I first fell for them when I moved here for undergrad.  The mountains north of campus were the first thing that stole my breath away. Sure, the university has its own beauty with its buildings, ponds, and trees – they hold a special place in my heart too. But those mountains, they rule it all.

The town itself is pretty amazing. There are so many cute cafés where I spent countless hours fueled by caffeine and studying. Just a short walk or bus ride away, you're in the downtown area, surrounded by old buildings with faded bricks, giving it this old-world charm. It's like a mini-city with its own hustle and bustle. But step past the library, and you're back in that peaceful small-town vibe. This mix of atmospheres, right next to each other, makes this place so special. It's like it's begging you to explore it.

It's easy to make lasting memories here.  Maybe it's walking past rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter, or racing through downtown to catch a movie at that fancy theater the university gave us tickets to. But, like all places, there are tough memories too. The ponds, especially, are a good spot for both reflection and crying sessions at 2 am when you're having an existential crisis, which, let's be honest, I've done more than a few times.  

Watching the turtles, ducks, and bugs just living their lives, each with their own purpose, makes me wonder about my own place in the world. Sometimes, I walk past the pond, past the park, past those little houses that scream "suburbia," until I reach a main street.  Then, the sun shines its golden rays on the palm trees, painting the sky, and as I look up at the sunrise, I realize I'm walking north. And there they are, just like they always are. Those strong mountains, towering over everything else, touching the hazy blue and yellow sky. They don't say a word, but they remind me to keep going.

Okay, so you're thinking of checking out Bensonhurst, Brooklyn? Finding it is a piece of cake! The subway is super easy to use here, and it's how most New Yorkers get around. Bensonhurst is definitely a city neighborhood, so you'll still be right in the heart of it all. 

One thing that really stands out in Bensonhurst is all the Asian stores.  Over the past twenty years, a ton of Asian folks have moved here, so you'll practically see an Asian-owned shop on every block. Supermarkets and laundromats seem to be the most popular, and guess what? They're super loved by the locals! The food in the supermarkets is amazing, the prices are way better than other places, and it's just so convenient to have them right around the corner. I'm serious, there are like four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk from where I live! Talk about convenient grocery shopping!

Now, don't think Bensonhurst is only for Asians though. It's actually a really mixed bag of people, with immigrants, first-generation Americans, and second-generation Americans all living here. But, most of the bigger stores and businesses around are owned by Asians.

Oh, and there's this awesome park nearby that's been recently redone. It's got ten basketball courts, a huge field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for them to cool off in the summer. It's a real melting pot of people there, all playing and getting along great.

You won't find any giant corporate buildings in Bensonhurst. Mostly, it's co-op buildings or condos.  A lot of people live in two-family houses, too. The people here are generally pretty cool, but they can be loud! You'll hear cars blasting music all day long, and sometimes they even rev their engines so loud that it wakes you up in the morning.

If you're visiting at night, just be a little careful. Bensonhurst is safe for the most part, but you never know. There are some folks who like to cause trouble for no reason, and you might run into some bullies or even thieves. I've had a couple of run-ins with bullies in the past, but that was years ago.  Just recently, I heard about someone who had their package stolen, so be aware of that too.

One last thing - don't expect people to clean up after their dogs here. Even though there are fines for not doing so, nobody really seems to care.  Every day, you'll probably see dog poop on your way to the train station or the supermarket. It's my biggest pet peeve! Just be careful and keep your shoes clean.

My neighborhood is kinda unique, ya know?  It's like everything slopes downward, and my house sits right at the top of the biggest hill around.  People call it the "workout hill" 'cause all the joggers love to run up it.  The thing is, there aren't any sidewalks, so everyone just walks on the road.  It's a bit bumpy in places, and honestly, kinda scary to drive on sometimes.  Plus, the power lines and phone lines are all tangled up and look kinda ancient.  We get a lot of rain and storms here, so branches and stuff always knock down the power lines.  They're always patching them up, which makes them look all patchworky. 

Everywhere you look, there are these giant evergreen trees.  But, here's the kicker, everyone hates them!  They try to chop them down as much as possible because they block the view of the ocean.  That's why so many houses are built way up on the hill, with these huge windows on the second floor just to catch a glimpse of the bay.

Sunsets are pretty amazing though. The water lights up from below, and the sky turns this fiery orange.  But, it's usually cloudy, so you mostly see the sun through this hazy veil.  It's pretty much overcast and damp most of the time.  Moss grows on everything – roofs, cars, even railings!  Once, I left my car in the driveway for a month, and it was practically covered in green, furry moss. Took me forever to scrape it all off.

There aren't many kids around here. There's a school just a few blocks away, but most of the people are older folks, mostly retired.  Instead of kids, they have dogs. You see them everywhere - hanging out in lawns or chasing each other down the street.  Be careful if you leave a door or window open, 'cause they'll sneak right in! I found one once in my living room and had to shoo him out. 

Rabbits are a bit of a nuisance too. They're pretty big and gardeners hate them because they dig up plants and burrow in lawns.  My cats, though, they love a good rabbit hunt and have practically cleared them out of the neighborhood.  We also have the usual birds – sparrows, hummingbirds, and sometimes a hawk or eagle swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off.

There aren't any stores around here, but if you hike down to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants serving up fresh seafood. The beach isn't much to write home about, but the rocks along the shore are fun to chuck into the water. The bay isn't very wide – you can see the other side even through the mist most days.

Y'all, let me tell you about my little corner of the world, right here in a quiet little town in Tennessee.  We're talkin' a real sleepy suburb, nestled between two big ol' highways. That means we get a bit more traffic than a fella might like, but other than that, it's peaceful as can be. Folks around here mostly keep to themselves, tending to their yards and such.  Wintertime, though, that's when the fun begins! We got a little hill right off our street, perfect for sledding. We live smack dab on the corner, so we see everybody comin' and goin'.  We know all the folks around here, their cars, their dogs, the whole shebang.  Whenever we see somethin' new rollin' through, well, we take notice.  Some folks like to take walks, stretch their legs, or just let their dogs sniff around. Kids on bikes, the usual kid stuff, you know?  We're homebodies at heart, workin' from home ourselves. It's just me, my wife, and our two little girls, eleven and fourteen.  So, folks are used to seein' us pop in and out, just livin' our lives.

We love to get outside, rain or shine!  Sometimes we fire up the grill on our back deck, and the smell of barbecue just fills the air.  You can't help but smile when that happens. Seems like there's always somebody mowin' their lawn around here, 'specially between March and October when that grass grows like crazy. We got a whole lotta trees around, 'cause this place used to be woods.  It's pretty shady, but come Fall, we're knee-deep in leaves. That means rakin' and burnin' 'em up, which I gotta say, smells mighty good. It's like Fall's official scent!

Lately, we ain't had much of a winter, so it feels like Fall's just hangin' around for dear life. Our garage is in the back, so we mostly use the front door when someone comes knockin', which ain't very often. I like to tinker in the garage on my truck or other projects.  When those garage doors are up, I feel like I'm right in the middle of it all.  Holidays are pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving brings some family from out of town and cars are parked everywhere. Same goes for Mother's Day and Christmas.

All in all, I wouldn't trade this place for the world. If it weren't for those pesky highways, it'd be perfect.

My neighborhood, it's right smack dab in the middle of the high desert, ya know?  Dirt, dirt, and more dirt.  Unless you've lived here, it's hard to understand that feeling, always seeing brown.  And when you do see a green lawn, you just know that person is spending a fortune on keeping it that way.  Back when I first moved here in the 90s, the houses were spread out, wide open spaces. Now, it's getting a bit more crowded, lots of new houses popping up.  Honestly, it feels more like a city every day, but I guess that's how things go everywhere these days.  

The people here are mostly friendly, though, like anywhere, you've got your good and your bad.  I'm surrounded by really nice old folks, so I guess you could say it's a pretty decent neighborhood.  

As for stores, it's mostly the big chain stores you see everywhere: Food 4 Less, Smart & Final, that kind of thing.  If you want something more upscale, you gotta drive a bit.  Never see any Whole Foods or anything like that around here.  

Looking around, most jobs seem to be in construction.  I figure that's because the city's still growing, lots of open land to build on.  It kind of scares me, though.  I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not looking to go back.

Speaking of construction, that's what I do for a living, actually.  Drywall and T-bar installation.   

What I love about this place is all the critters.  People come to the high desert for all sorts of reasons, but the stark beauty of the desert itself is a big draw.  It's a tough environment, but it has its own unique charm and it's home to all kinds of amazing wildlife.  We humans gotta learn to share this space with them and live together peacefully.

My family and I have gotten used to sharing our home with the wildlife. I got three kids, and they're totally obsessed with lizards and desert bugs! Right now, as I'm typing this, they're outside trying to catch some. 

There are a few things to do around here, too.  Victorville is a good place for families, especially if you want a different kind of experience.  If you're visiting, try to time it with the San Bernardino County Fair - it's a blast!  And if you head up to Wrightwood nearby, you can see the snow-capped mountains and take some winter sports lessons.

Want to learn more about the desert's history and nature? The Victor Valley Museum has some great stuff - rocks, fossils, Native American artifacts, and old stuff from Victorville's past.

Hmm, describing my neighborhood is kinda different from what everyone else might say.  While they probably talk about houses and backyards, my neighborhood is the college campus I call home. My dorm mates are my community, and the whole campus is my stomping ground.  It's a bit unique, I know, but it still has those neighborhood vibes. You've got your "houses," your people, your shops, and even a park. Let me break it down for you.

First, the "houses" - we've got apartments, actual houses for rent, and those classic dorm rooms.  Apartments have a few people per room, maybe 4 or 6 rooms per floor, with a couple of floors in a building. That's like 20 people in each building, give or take. Then there are the houses, more like family homes, mostly for alumni,  but not many of those around. And lastly, the dorm rooms, where most of us live – two people sharing, tons of students, the whole shebang.

My school is all about diversity, and that's what makes my neighborhood so interesting. You've got people from all walks of life, all ages. The staff usually live in those houses, newer students are in the dorms, and the older ones grab the apartments. It's a melting pot, really.

And let's not forget the shops and the park!  We've got all sorts of places to eat, campus-branded clothes and groceries - you name it, we've got it! And the park? It's our little oasis, lively and safe, thanks to everyone looking out for each other.

So yeah, my neighborhood might be a bit different, but it's got all the heart and soul of any good community.

Hmm...my heart goes out to my old neighbourhood, Stockbridge. Ten years have flown by since we moved from Riverdale. I gotta admit, when we first arrived, it felt like a punch to the gut.  I missed my friends back in Riverdale, they were family to me. But my folks, bless their hearts, wanted the best for us. They thought Stockbridge would be a fresh start, a place where we could shine. A better school, a nicer house, you know, all that jazz.  

It took time, but I adjusted. Made some new friends, some who became super close, and some, well, let's just say they weren't so great.  Truth be told, I never really got to know most of the neighbours, except for Mr. Glen and his family, and Dennis for a bit, since they lived right next door. They're like family to me, so warm and welcoming. I'll never forget Mr. Glen's wedding (his second time down the aisle!). It was a blast, a real party. I even caught his wife's garter! Wish I'd snagged the bouquet too though. We danced the night away, and had a great time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. Haven't seen her in ages, hope she's doing well.

This neighbourhood's a bit of a labyrinth, but I've got a GPS now, so I'm slowly exploring every nook and cranny.  Most of my adventures have been with my buddies Kason and Curtis. We were inseparable, spending hours glued to video games, just living life to the fullest. Sometimes I'd escape to the park, soak in the fresh air, let nature soothe my soul. It's my happy place. I even practice my balance with sticks from Home Depot and bring my bokken (wooden sword) sometimes. The park also has a basketball and tennis court, though I haven't touched a racket or ball in ages. Still cool to have them there for when I feel like dusting off the old skills. My dad got me and my best friend into tennis with Mr. Graves. We had a blast, even though he pushed us hard! 

Looking back, I've made so many memories here, so many stories I could tell. But these are the ones that stick out: the warmth of Mr. Glen's family, the nights with Kason and Curtis, and the peace I find in the park. Stockbridge will always hold a special place in my heart. And you know what? I think the best is yet to come!

Hmm...my current digs are pretty close to my school, which is a major plus. Mostly, it's all apartments around here, but there are a few little eateries and watering holes that are fun to hang out at, and they won't break the bank either. One of those bars just got a new name, and now it's a bit pricier, but the drinks and service are still decent. Most folks are alright, either students or folks who are on a tighter budget, since the apartments aren't too fancy.  There are quite a few kiddos around, thanks to the elementary school just a hop, skip, and a jump away. I don't really know my neighbors, and to be honest, I'm not too keen on getting to know them either. They seem to be bigtime weed enthusiasts, so the building management put an air freshener right by their door. My boyfriend and I found it hilarious, almost like a slap in the face, you know?  The buildings around here are kinda old-fashioned, but some of them have probably been spruced up inside.  

Down the street, there are these brand-spanking-new apartments, but I'm not a fan. They look cheap, even if the rent is sky-high. It's a total rip-off, but because they're near campus, the management can get away with it. Speaking of places to eat, there's this super cheap joint about five minutes away that serves everything on paper plates, and most of it is microwaved. Across the street from there is a gas station, and I heard working there is a nightmare. However, thanks to some city dough, they redid the road last summer. Now, there's a wide sidewalk, lots of grass on the sides, and the whole area looks a bit more polished. 

My building is covered in trees, though they chopped down a few, leaving some stumps. There are way more trees where I live compared to down the road. Behind my complex is a row of trees, and then another set of apartments. I'm on 42nd street, but behind me is 43rd, and that one isn't as charming. The sidewalks are practically falling apart, and the buildings look pretty shabby. There are a lot of trees there too, probably trying to hide the state of things. Most of the crime in the area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but I guess you can't blame them entirely. There are some other apartments across from me that have their fair share of crime and a revolving door of residents. 

But honestly, I kind of like where I live. It's affordable, and there are plenty of things I need nearby. I especially love that the university is just a walk away, and there are two bus stops that make it easy to get to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood is like a little slice of heaven, hidden away on a cul-de-sac. Each house is a duplex, spaced out so they look like individual homes.  They all wear the same sunny yellow paint and white porches, topped with bright green metal roofs. Almost everyone here knows each other, like a big, friendly family. Sometimes, we gather at the end of the road - no one really decides to meet, it just happens - and chat while the little ones play. It's so peaceful here, a real escape from all the hustle and bustle of the modern world. Feels like stepping back in time, surrounded by fields and trees, with a big blue sky above and fluffy white clouds drifting by.

But even in this idyllic place, things can change in a flash. We've had tornado warnings lately, and last night, the sirens actually went off!  We all scurried for shelter. I grabbed my baby dog, my purse, and a couple of pillows and headed for the bathtub, feeling a little silly but safe. My big dog, well, he wasn't so keen on the idea of a bathroom bunker and stayed in the living room, whining and barking. Outside, the storm raged, with giant hailstones pounding the ground. After it passed, the road was literally steaming!  The temperature dropped from 92 degrees to 75 in minutes, and the hail melted instantly on the hot pavement. 

As the clouds parted, the sun came out and the sky burst into a double rainbow. I rushed inside for my camera, snapping pictures to share with my family and friends. Everyone was amazed, just like me. The neighborhood stayed quiet for a while, with everyone probably still in shock.  Then, things went back to normal – moms and kids back outside, dinner cooking, the friendly chatter resuming. My heart swells with gratitude for finding this wonderful community.  

It’s such a joy living here,  especially after moving from New Hampshire to North Carolina.  Though everyone has the same two-bed, two-bath apartments, each home is unique inside. Some are tiny, which seems odd. But hey, that's part of the charm!

I love to walk through the big field behind my place down to the pond (no swimming allowed, though!). I’ve seen deer there and in the mornings, a giant bullfrog serenades me with his song. It's a beautiful place to live, just a hop, skip, and a jump from Charlotte. Every morning starts with the sound of roosters crowing from nearby farms. It feels like a little village, with a donkey at a nearby farm braying in the evenings.

I'm so lucky to have found this little piece of paradise.

Hmm...my heart n soui went to this neighborhood right as I was starting eighth grade. It was kinda hard to make friends at first, but then I met this awesome guy who lives two houses down and another one down the street. Neither of them live there now, but I still think about them. Most of the people who were here when I first moved in are still around. My neighborhood is pretty much like any other American suburb, you know? Lots of two-story houses, and every time the weather's nice, you hear kids playing outside. It's pretty quiet most days. I've never had any problems with anyone around here. You can be pretty much left alone unless you need something, which is nice. I've ordered tons of stuff online, and my packages have always been safe. I trust my neighbors. There's this park just a hop, skip, and a jump from my house. I've got tons of memories there. Me and the guys used to play basketball, football, and baseball there all the time.  I even got a pretty nasty elbow to the nose playing football, but those good times definitely outweigh the bad ones. Now, when I go there, it's mostly to hang out with my cousin's kids. They're way younger than me, and they still love going on swings and down slides. Just thinking about going there makes them so excited. The park makes me feel all nostalgic, you know?  My neighborhood is pretty diverse. There's all kinds of food around here - Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian - you name it! But nowadays, most people just get their food delivered with apps like GrubHub and DoorDash. The most popular places are the fast food joints, which you can find pretty much anywhere. There are tons of pizza places, too. The stores around here have everything you could ever need. There are a bunch of dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and even a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is pretty popular around here. And some of them are even unique, like this Indian-owned store where you can get all the ingredients you need to make some awesome home-cooked Indian food, or even grab some ready-made meals. Overall, I love living here. Seeing all the crazy stories about neighbors on the news and social media makes me so thankful for the people around me.

My little town, Johnston, is like a sweet little peach nestled in South Carolina. It ain't no fancy place, just a regular ol' town, but it's got a heart of gold, especially when it comes to peaches. They call it the Peach Capital of the World, and you know they take that seriously!  

Everywhere you look, it's either peach trees as far as the eye can see or fields full of cows. The houses spread out like stars in the night sky, mostly two-story beauties with metal roofs to beat the summer heat or those classic gray shingles. Most of them ain't right on the road, they're tucked back in their own little world with fields out front for the animals or crops. 

The whole town kinda revolves around this one stoplight, the heart of it all, where you'll find the only stores in town. Got your fast food fix at Hong Kong, the Chinese joint run by a family, Fiesta for some Mexican spice, or Gary's for a good ol' burger. Used to have a pizza place, but it closed down a while back, which is a real bummer.  There's Maxwell and Halford Drug, a tiny pharmacy known for their legendary Cherry Coca-Cola. And then there's IGA, the grocery store, kinda pricey but the only one around. Most folks go to Batesburg-Leesville for their big grocery hauls, though. 

But the real star of the show is Dollar General! It's packed from morning till night with folks grabbing everyday essentials.  

Then there's Possibilities Furniture & More, run by this sweet lady who's a fixture in town. She's been there forever and even has movers to deliver your purchases! Right next door is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, where your furry friends can get pampered with baths, haircuts, and even daycare.

The doctor and vet are off the beaten path a little, but they're good folks, always there to help. And there's Johnston Elementary, where kids learn their ABCs until fifth grade. After that, they have to head to the next town for middle and high school. 

Don't expect any fancy parks or playgrounds here, but they're working on creating a little recreational area.  Truth be told, there ain't much to do in Johnston. No movie theaters, bowling alleys, or hang-out spots. But it's a good town, real friendly, and blink and you might just miss it!

The first time I heard about my place, it was on a podcast about missing persons. It was a bit of a shocker, you know? I mean, every apartment in this area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I never heard a peep about anything like that, and neither did my friends. Maybe it's just life, I guess. I know a few friends who cry themselves to sleep at night, ya know? Things are tight, but we've learned to make do over the years. You start appreciating the dustiest of flea market toys, the worn-out clothes that smell like memories. You don't smell as much as an adult, I guess. Maybe you start smoking, or maybe you just get used to the way things are. But the flea market always calls to you.  The smell of adulthood is like dusty magazines piled on a piano, waiting to be played. It sinks into the leather, stays with you even after you wash it. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. You can start on one end and hit up two charity shops, a library, a rare books store, and a curio shop. Downtown is a madhouse, cars and people everywhere in the morning, but you wouldn't hear a thing in those thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars go by, it's always quiet. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there are more and more of those. Cars and people, they just keep pouring in. It's a growing city, they say. Headquartered for one of the biggest online empires, you can see the pains of growing up.  Reminds me of New York, actually. Everyone's focused on their own thing, no one really expects much from you. You can be alone, quiet, independent, and folks will leave you be.  Not like back home, in the South, where a little concern means you care. People don't pry into your life here, not really. You can keep your walls up as long as you want, and the city just rolls on, like waves crashing on the beach. It's a lively place to be, though. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we're less like apartments of strangers and more like a community of friends. We come together for birthdays, funerals, help each other out when we can. I'm lucky to be here, I guess. I like most of my neighbors, and they treat me pretty good. I try to keep things clean, leave them food, and they do the same. We bring each other mail, stuff like that. It's nice to see them, and I think they like me being around, too. I live in this massive, impersonal concrete jungle, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't completely screw up my life.

My neighbourhood, well, it's like stepping into a picture postcard of suburbia, you know? Every nook and cranny screams "cookie cutter" and the homeowner's association is like the captain of this perfectly manicured ship.  

Just picture this: neat, tidy single-family homes lining the streets, all looking like twins.  The front yards are basically carbon copies of each other - a patch of green grass, some decorative pebbles, and driveways that seem too short for two cars. You'll spot a few trees here and there, but not many.  It's all very... predictable. 

And speaking of predictability, the roads are always spotless! No potholes or cracks mar the freshly paved concrete.  Most houses are single-story, but occasionally you'll stumble upon a two-story beauty. 

But forget those traditional mailboxes you see on TV, we do things differently here.  No individual boxes in front of each house, no sir! It's more like an apartment complex with a giant bank of mailboxes at the end of the street. You need a special key to open yours, and there are even bigger lockers for packages.  The HOA really loves their uniformity, you see.

My house sits on the edge of the city, so it's a bit of a hybrid - part suburbia, part country.  We have a lot of space, which means there are multiple community pools (they're gated and sparkling clean!) and walking trails perfect for a stroll with your dog or a peaceful evening walk.  You don't even need to go to a park to get your exercise in, just run around the neighborhood!

Most of the people here are retired folks, which makes the area incredibly safe and friendly.  Everyone looks out for each other.   We also have a sprinkle of middle-aged and young professionals mixed in.

The city itself is surprisingly big, but it has that small-town charm.  We have all the necessary amenities, like a single mall (not huge, but it gets the job done!). It's a quick 15-minute drive to get to the bigger shopping centers, where you can find everything from fancy organic groceries to bargain stores with bare-bones staff and minimal selection.

All in all, my neighborhood is pretty typical, safe, well-maintained, and comfortable. We have pools, trails, and a sense of community. It's not right next to a bustling city center, but a short drive gets you there.

My life here in this small town, tucked away just outside a big city, is kinda like a mixed bag, you know? Where we live, on the east side, it's not the fanciest place. Houses are older, mostly rented out, and things can get a bit rough around the edges. But honestly, it's not bad. People are friendly, always waving and saying hello. Sure, there's been some trouble, like a few shootings and even a murder, but it's not like it's constant. It's heartbreaking when something like that happens, like when our neighbors lost their son last year in a shooting.  For us, it's been mostly just the occasional thing going missing from our porch if we forget to bring it in.  

But the whole opioid thing, that's been tough on our town, like everywhere else, I guess. It's taken some good people from us. But thankfully, there's a lot of support here, with places to get help and programs for families dealing with this stuff.

Honestly, there's a lot to love about this town too. My son goes to a fantastic elementary school. The teachers and the principal, they're all amazing. He's got some special needs, but he's never been bullied there, everyone is so accepting. They even have a great PTO that does all sorts of things to keep families involved.  Because a lot of folks here struggle financially, the school makes sure every kid gets breakfast and lunch, no questions asked. It's a real community effort, you know?

The town itself has been working hard to improve things, fixing up roads, parks, and making it look nicer. But it seems like most of the attention is focused on the west side, where the shopping is and everything. Our side, the east side, we're left behind a little bit.  

Overall, I'm happy here. It's home. People are good, the schools are great, there's enough to do, and our house, well, it might not be worth much, but it's ours. We've been here for over 16 years, and I can't imagine leaving.

My neighborhood, it's a real melting pot, you know?  It's perched on a hill, surrounded by buildings that have stories to tell. My apartment building is seven stories high, right across from this old theater that's seen its share of history.  Down the hill, just a block away, is this cool little bar that attracts all sorts of folks, especially on warm summer nights. You'll often see a line of people stretching down the block, especially on weeknights in June and July. A few blocks up is a park, a pretty decent-sized one for this part of town. It's fenced off with concrete, and there are these tall stairs built right into the wall. Come winter, when it gets really cold, you'll see homeless folks setting up their tents in neat little rows along the sidewalk and on those wide steps. It doesn't snow much here, but the rain in the middle of winter can be brutal.  They stay close together, right in the heart of the city, for warmth. Plus, it's not far to walk or take the bus to the nearest family center, where they can get a hot shower and a bit of a break.

But honestly, what I love most about this city isn't the old buildings or the history—though there's plenty of that. It's the people. You see, Hilltop used to be known as the most dangerous place on the West Coast, back in the day. Even now, thirty years later, you hear stories about the government agents and the DEA trying to clean up the streets. It's something that's woven into the fabric of this place, passed down from generation to generation, even to newcomers like me.  Even though people still say it's one of the rougher neighborhoods in the city, they work hard to keep it clean and safe. They care about what happens on their block, in their city.

They'll tell you not to walk around Hilltop after dark if you're white. I think that's just a remnant of the old days, a bit of outdated thinking. Maybe it's because I'm dark enough to blend in, or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who gets it. Someone who knows about the whispers of racism and prejudice that still linger, even in a place that's supposed to be a melting pot. 

One thing's for sure: no matter where I go, Hilltop will always be home. There's a vibrancy here, a sense of community that I feel in my bones. I feel safe walking these streets at night, meeting people who are more likely to offer me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where the laundromat owner will stay open late so I can charge my phone when I'm caught in a downpour. It's a place where I can sit huddled on a cold night, feeling invisible, only to have someone look me in the eye, hand me a five-dollar bill, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

My life unfolds in the heart of Rural America, in a quaint little town nestled in Michigan. It's a world where rolling farmlands gently transition into charming tourist spots. Forget about towering city malls, bustling Wal-marts, or even the familiar red brick facade of an Applebee's. Here, every adventure, every errand, requires a journey behind the wheel. But despite this quiet simplicity, I reside in a place of breathtaking beauty, embraced by the shimmering waters of two magnificent lakes: the vast expanse of Lake Michigan and the picturesque Lake Charlevoix. Every turn reveals a new beach, beckoning you to dip your toes into the cool embrace of the water.

My neighborhood embodies the true essence of small-town charm. Houses aren't crammed together like sardines in a can; they stand proudly, each with its own unique story to tell. Some have been lovingly restored, their vintage charm enhanced with modern touches, while others retain their original character, whispering tales of bygone eras. Most have full basements, their presence evident from the street, and the siding often sports a classic aluminum sheen. 

My block is a kaleidoscope of colors, with houses painted in every hue imaginable. Gardens bursting with life, vibrant fences enclosing playful pets, and gleaming trampolines and swings in backyards – these are the hallmarks of our community. It's a tapestry woven with the threads of hard-working families, raising children who fill the streets with their laughter.

The pace of life here is gentle, a soothing melody of familiar sights and sounds. Children's laughter echoes through the streets, accompanied by the pitter-patter of dog paws and the gentle whir of bicycle wheels. Neighbors greet each other with friendly waves and smiles, a sense of belonging woven into the very fabric of our community. Well-manicured lawns, free from fallen leaves and overgrown weeds, reflect a pride in our homes and our shared space.

This isn't a neighborhood that boasts extravagant mansions or dazzling facades. Its beauty lies in its simplicity, its quiet strength, and the undeniable sense of safety and comfort it offers. It's a place where families flourish, where children are free to play, and where the worries of the world melt away.

Just a stone's throw away, the county sheriff's department stands as a reassuring presence, a symbol of security. The health department and recycling center are close at hand, serving the needs of our community. The nearby baseball and softball fields buzz with the excitement of local games, while the small airport adds a touch of adventure to our daily lives, with the rumble of planes taking off and landing a constant reminder of the world beyond our borders. 

Life here is sweet, a symphony of everyday pleasures. A walk to the local ice cream parlor, a bike ride to the park – these are the simple joys that make our community special. It's a place where life unfolds at a slower pace, where neighbors become friends, and where the heart finds solace in the warmth of belonging.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them.
